entry.title: SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) | Customer Roundtable | October 2025
entry.content:
Customer Roundtable

It's time for a new edition of the CAP Roundtable - the first one after our highlight of the year - re>≡CAP 2025.

As always we will go for a mix of recent announcements, demo, presentations as well as topics and questions raised by the CAP community.

Do you have CAP related insights, requirements, issues, challenges, topics… that you would like to share and discuss in the upcoming meeting? If yes, please reach-out to us so that we can add it to the agenda.

 Agenda

  1. Introduction
  2. Updates from CAP Team
    • will be updated

  3. Q&A / Topics by the Community

Meeting Information

When: Wednesday, October 15th, 2025, 11 AM EST | 5 PM CE(S)T

Where: Teams Meeting

Meeting Request Download: link 

Who:  

    • All interested partners and stakeholders are invited to join: developers, enterprise architects, technical consultants…
    • The SAP Cloud Application Programming Model team
    • Anyone interested in learning about the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and exchange your ideas and feedback with other users and the product team

Looking forward to seeing you there!
Check also out the new Events page in our documentation and our Community page for updates on upcoming events.

entry.title: Non-MRP-Relevant Storage Location Appears in Stock in APO Product View
entry.content:
Hi everyone,


we’re encountering an issue in the SAP APO Product View for a particular material. A storage location that is not MRP-relevant is unexpectedly appearing in the stock overview, and its quantity is being included in the total available quantity.


In SAP ECC, I’ve checked table T001L, and the storage location is clearly flagged as not relevant for MRP. For other materials that also have stock in this same storage location, the quantity is correctly excluded from the APO Product View.


This leads us to suspect that there might be a material-dependent override somewhere that causes this behavior.
Does anyone know if there’s another configuration point, possibly material-specific, that could influence whether a storage location is considered in APO stock calculations?


Thanks in advance for your insights!

entry.title: Re: How to display custom MIGO fields in Stock – Multiple...
entry.content:
Hello @Tharma 

SAP currently does not permit adding new custom fields directly into the standard Stock – Multiple Materials app (F1595) in Public Cloud.

What is supported is the Data Source Extension to expose existing SAP fields if they are available in the app’s underlying data source.

If you need new attributes, the supported option is to develop a separate custom report or app.


For future changes, the official places to check or request are SAP Road Map Explorer and Customer Influence
Reference: SAP Fiori App Library – F1595 “Stock – Multiple Materials” (App Extensibility)

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Using Technical User in SAP Datasphere Consumption APIs (Client Credentials)
entry.content:
Hi @anton-malyshev,

We expected that DW Scoped Consumer has all necessary permissions but for some reason this one is missing. Is it by design or maybe that can be fixed? 

That is true, for the moment DW Scoped Consumer has not all the permissions required, that is limitation we are aware. We are working on making the "Data Warehouse Data Builder (-R------)" not mandatory for the Consumption APIs, this should be release later this year or early 2026.

If you want to have a scoped role with only those 3 permission, you can:

  1. Create a Custom Role (Non-Scoped) with only the 3 permissions needed and read privilege
  2. Next use this newly created role as the template for creating Custom Scoped Role
  3. Assign the new Custom Scoped Role to you Technical User

This should give you all flexibility to use the least privilege for you consumption technical user

entry.title: Getting the list of transport requests which will be deployed from SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Dear Community,

We are in the process of evaluating the gaps between our Solution Manager ChaRM implementation and SAP Cloud ALM, in preparation for the decomissioning of Solution Manager.

One of the points which is rather critical for us, is the ability of getting a list of the transport requests which will be considered for deployment. We use this list to run our "release integrity checks" via 3rd party tools, which has proven quite often to be a very valuable activity preventing serious issues in our productive systems.

It seems that the Features Overview dashboard (screenshot below) would be an appropriate place to get such a list. However, the mandatory Project filter is preventing us from getting a comprehensive list of all Features which would be deployed, forcing us to get this list project by project, which could become prohibitively time consuming.

Would there be a way to remove this project assignment as a filter? Or would you know of some other way to get this list of features (and respective transport requests) which are in a certain status, belonging to a certain release (or deployment plan)?

Thanks so much!

entry.title: Curriculum Requirements with Retraining
entry.content:
Dear experts,

We are building a curriculum with curriculum requirement, where users need to complete 15 hours out of an item pool by the end of the year. At the beginning of the next year, the item pool is reviewed with some new trainings, but also some old trainings.

Every year, the users need to reach the 15 hours-benchmark again (starting from 0). We should make sure that completing a previously-completed item is prevented, or at least does not contribute in the 15-hour count. This means that every year, the user receives a pool with old and new items, and should obtain 15 training-hours by the end of the year, choosing between the courses that they didn't follow yet. The courses are a mix of e-learnings and instructor-led items, so preventing registrations via the internal is not sufficient.

Could you please advice me how to build such process?

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud - SUM of Subtotals is not matchin...
entry.content:
Hi Martin,

The issue happens because missing daily records make subtotals and totals use different bases for calculation.
The fix is to calculate TotalFTE first at the day level as FTE * Quota.
Then aggregate upwards to month, quarter, or year using SUM of DailyFTE as numerator.
For denominator, count only the valid days where data exists (DailyFTE > 0).
This way, Org Units with partial data and those with full data follow the same logic.
As a result, subtotals and overall totals will always align correctly.

entry.title: Update to our Rules of Engagement
entry.content:
We have updated our Rules of Engagement today.

To explain in short what has changed since the last version: 

  • Article 1 now describes the participation etiquette that we expect all community members to follow, as well as outlines the general rules for content publication. For more in-depth information on the participation etiquette and tips for participation in the community, please read this article in our Welcome Corner group. 
  • Article 2 contains information on user profile information. 
  • Article 3 describes content which constitutes "Unacceptable Content". Content that is listed in article 3 may either by rejected or removed. The categories here are now aligned with changes the EU made to the Digital Services Act (DSA) categories this year. All abuse reports under article 3 will be subject to DSA.
  • The old article 3 has been removed, which means publishing content about job opportunities and job postings are no longer permitted in the SAP Community.
  • Article 4 has not changed and remains the same. 

With these updates to our rules of engagement, we continue to ensure the best possible content quality and community experience for our members..

entry.title: country field from Candidate profile template to Employee profile field for internal Hiring-SAP RCM
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

Good day...

As per the current requirement ,The customers wants to have the "County"(Residence of Country) Field in Internal Candidate Profile and this value should capture from Employee profile to Candidate Profile. As per the current setup the "County"(Residence of Country)field is not set up as picklist in employee profile, Hence the details not get captured in Candidate Profile in country field when there is a internal Hiring. However when we Changing data type in Employee Profile for country field in Employee central - SF will impact all the downstream system from SF to SAP. Kindly let me know do we have any alternative solution to achieve this requirement.

Hence We have done an impact analysis and we  found : 

S.No

Option

Feasibility

Comments

1

– EP country field to Candidate profile

No

Data type is different from Employee profile and candidate data model

2

Enable “country of residence” for Internal to edit in respective profiles

No

By standard, this field is not enabled for internals. Based on KBAs it needs to be updated through SM mapping only which we cannot do as per above comment

3

Create custom country field in candidate profile and do SM mapping

No

We don’t have flag to differentiate between Internal & external candidate in OData dictionary. So, we cannot maintain this logic in IC job to read custom country field for internals and standard country field for externals

4

Utilize Phone country / Region in IC job

No

This field is available in UI only not in Data dictionary. So, we cannot use this to send the preference to paradox through IC Job

Kindly let me know if we have alternative solutions for this approach.

Regards

PREM

@M_jess1 @xavierlegarrec @Gopinath_Murugaiyan    SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting

entry.title: Mapping multiple pay components from SuccessFactors Recruitment to Employee Central
entry.content:
In this article we will discuss an issue relating to mapping multiple pay components from SuccessFactors Recruitment to Employee Central.  This is particularly useful when you want internal hires to go to Manage Pending Hires rather than initiate Onboarding.

In the application template we are saving the amount, frequency and type for four different pay components.  When we move the candidate into Manage Pending Hires we see that there are  multiple rows of data.

The first check was to create a rule trace to see if an Employee Central rule was creating this extra line.  The rule trace confirmed that it was not related to a rule.  

In the mapping template we had multiple rows for each pay component.

The multiple mapping rows for each pay component was causing the issue.  You do not need to map the code, amount and type as three different mappings.  You only need to map one line as shown below, as the amount value sets the pay component with ‘.1001’.

<mapping-attribute><source entity-type="application" refid="offer_HOURLYrateofPay"/><target refid="payComponentRecurring.paycompvalue.1001"/></mapping-attribute>

The frequency does not need to be mapped as this should default from rule in Employee Central.

As mentioned on a previous article you can send internal hires to Manage Pending Hires and review the data there for internal hires before deciding whether you need to initiate an onboarding process.

entry.title: Re: Real-Time Inventory Sync in Composable Storefront with SAP Commerce Cloud
entry.content:
Hi Balaji,

Thank you for responding.

The use case is to ensure that customers browsing the composable storefront always see accurate stock levels without delays, especially during high-traffic events like sales or product launches. The business need is to avoid overselling while maintaining a smooth user experience.

We are evaluating whether an event-driven approach (e.g., publishing inventory changes from SAP Commerce Cloud in near real-time) would be more efficient than frequent API polling, as API calls could introduce latency or performance overhead. At the same time, we want to understand the best practices for handling inventory synchronization at scale; where thousands of SKUs are involved, without affecting site performance.

Would appreciate guidance on whether SAP recommends a hybrid approach (event triggers plus periodic reconciliation) or if there’s an established reference architecture for such scenarios.

entry.title: Implementation of a taxable entity across system boundaries (public cloud ↔ private cloud) using DRC
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We have a complex requirement in the context of implementing a taxable entity involving company codes from different SAP system landscapes.

Initial situation:

  • The client XXXX XXXX is on an SAP private cloud system with a taxable entity that includes several company codes.
  • XXXX XXXX is now to be included in this taxable entity. However, it is on an SAP public cloud system as a single company code.

Problem:

  • VAT returns are currently submitted on a monthly basis.
  • A manual workaround using the FOTV app (maintenance of an external value) in the private cloud system would be possible in general, but doesn’t go with the requirements of the client
  • During pre-sales, the client was assured that an automated interface between the public cloud and private cloud would be possible, allowing data to be transferred without manual intervention.

Internal discussion status:

  • It was proposed to use Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) in a hybrid solution involving Lobster (the XXXX XXXX uses Lobster as a middleware on which all interfaces must be mapped – no BTP + CPI).
  • The client has a total of 5 company codes, 4 in the Private Cloud system and 1 in the Public Cloud system.

Specific questions:

  1. DRC licensing:
  • Which licensing models apply to hybrid use of DRC across public and private clouds?
  • Is licensing based on the number of company codes users, or, for example, the number of documents processed (e.g., blocks of 10,000 invoices)?
  1. Technical functionality:
  • Is it fundamentally possible with DRC to automatically merge company codes from different systems (public cloud ↔ private cloud) for taxable entity?
  • Or is a manual step – such as via FOTV – still necessary?
  1. Lobster integration:
  • Is there any experience or recommendations regarding the integration of Lobster as middleware between public cloud, private cloud, and DRC?
  • What requirements must be fulfilled for DRC to process data from the public cloud system?

Additional information:

  • The relevant DRC component for VAT returns in Germany is: FI-LOC-VAT-DE
  • We are aware that there is a separate DRC scenario for processing external data sources for electronic invoicing however, this does not appear to be the case for reporting. We would appreciate your feedback on the technical and licensing possibilities for implementation, as well as any suggestions for potential solutions. Thank you in advance.

Does anyone have any experience with this kind of topic?

I would appreciate any advice.

Thank you. 

@SAPSupport SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Finance SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Finance SAP Document and Reporting Compliance SAP S/4HANA Finance SAP Tax Classification and Reporting

entry.title: Re: Upload file in XSTRING format in SE38 report program
entry.content:
I'm probably late, but there's a solution to this problem. SAP handles the XSTRING, the hexadecimal string, and not the binary string when I try to display content using the various "viewers" available. So the GUI_UPLOAD solution is valid, but the conversion from BINARY to XSTRING is missing. Here's the code:

  DATA filename            TYPE string.
*  DATA FILETYPE            TYPE CHAR10.

*  DATA HEADER_LENGTH       TYPE I.
*  DATA READ_BY_LINE        TYPE CHAR01.

*  DATA CODEPAGE            TYPE ABAP_ENCODING.
*  DATA IGNORE_CERR         TYPE ABAP_BOOL.
*  DATA REPLACEMENT         TYPE ABAP_REPL.
*  DATA VIRUS_SCAN_PROFILE  TYPE VSCAN_PROFILE.
  DATA filelength          TYPE i.
*  DATA HEADER              TYPE XSTRING.
  DATA data_tab            TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF tdline.
*  DATA ISSCANPERFORMED     TYPE CHAR01.

  MOVE: url TO filename. "In this example i used variable url that contain the fullpath.

  cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_upload(
    EXPORTING
      filename                = filename
      filetype                = 'BIN'
*      has_field_separator     = SPACE
*      header_length           = 0
*      read_by_line            = 'X'
*      dat_mode                = SPACE
*      codepage                = SPACE
*      ignore_cerr             = ABAP_TRUE
*      replacement             = '#'
*      virus_scan_profile      = virus_scan_profile
    IMPORTING
      filelength              = filelength
*      header                  = header
    CHANGING
      data_tab                = data_tab
*      isscanperformed         = SPACE
    EXCEPTIONS
      file_open_error         = 1
      file_read_error         = 2
      no_batch                = 3
      gui_refuse_filetransfer = 4
      invalid_type            = 5
      no_authority            = 6
      unknown_error           = 7
      bad_data_format         = 8
      header_not_allowed      = 9
      separator_not_allowed   = 10
      header_too_long         = 11

         ).

  CHECK data_tab[] IS NOT INITIAL.

*DATA INPUT_LENGTH TYPE I.
*DATA FIRST_LINE   TYPE I.
*DATA LAST_LINE    TYPE I.
  DATA buffer       TYPE xstring.

  CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_BINARY_TO_XSTRING'
    EXPORTING
      input_length = filelength
*     FIRST_LINE   = 0
*     LAST_LINE    = 0
    IMPORTING
      buffer       = buffer

      binary_tab   = data_tab
    EXCEPTIONS
      failed       = 1.

entry.title: Enhancing Manufacturing Excellence: What's New in SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2508.1
entry.content:
Welcome to the release highlights for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.1 (HFC6). This update continues our commitment to delivering continuous innovation, with a strong focus on enhancing the user experience and operational efficiency for our customers in manufacturing. This post is particularly relevant for professionals in Production Planning, Production Engineering, and Manufacturing roles, as we are introducing several key improvements to help you manage your processes more effectively. I picked one release highlight - you can enjoy it in this short video here:  

 

 

Updates to Process Production Versions 

To improve the efficiency of managing production versions, we have introduced several quality-of-life updates to the Process Production Versions app. When performing mass edits, the system now defaults to background processing, freeing you up to work on other tasks. To prevent errors during cross-plant updates, an information message now appears to help you check for inconsistencies. This helps teams manage their data with greater confidence.

Task List Counter is auto-filled based on the selection of Task List Group while performing mass edits

Furthermore, you can now easily track the status of your mass edits with available logs and benefit from reduced manual entry, as the Task List Counter value is automatically filled when a Task List Group is selected.

 

Gaining Deeper Insights with the Successor to Monitor Production Orders or Process Orders

With the app Monitor Production Orders or Process Orders (F0266A), you can monitor the status of production orders or process orders in your area of responsibility. You can check whether the materials included in each order will be available on time and determine components and quantities that are delayed or missing. You can also check whether the milestones defined for an order are met. This helps you react quickly to critical situations and take appropriate actions as required.

As of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.1, a successor version of this app is available with the Monitor Production Orders or Process Orders (F0266B) app. This new app version will replace the old Monitor Production Orders or Process Orders (F0266A) app in the future. We recommend that you switch to the successor app as soon as possible.

The new app provides an improved look-and-feel based on the Fiori elements framework, while covering all essential features that are available from its predecessor. In addition, it allows you to easily switch between the lists of production orders and process orders without having to access it from different tiles, depending on the type of order that you want to display.

Production orders and process orders are displayed within the same app

 Both production orders and process orders are displayed within the same app.

 

A Refreshed Launchpad Experience for Production Planners

The SAP-delivered space template for Production Planning (SAP_BR_PRODN_PLNR) has been updated.

Space Template: Production Planning

If your business users are assigned the Production Planner business role template, they will experience a revised layout and an updated set of applications on their SAP Fiori launchpad. This change is designed to provide Production Planners with a more intuitive and role-based user experience. The updated space surfaces the most relevant apps and information, helping users perform their daily tasks more effectively and with fewer clicks.


Enhanced Visibility in Work Center Capacity Management

The Manage Work Center Capacity app now provides even greater transparency into your operations. Planners and supervisors can now view the associated Customer name and ID directly in a new column, which is especially useful for linking capacity requirements to specific make-to-order scenarios.

Customer name and Customer ID

Additionally, the application now clearly displays the Consolidated Shift Capacity and the Remaining Capacity.

Remaining capacity and consolidated shift capacity

 

This gives teams a more comprehensive view of utilization, helping them make more informed scheduling and load-leveling decisions to optimize the shop floor. 

 

Summary 

These highlights from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.1 update are designed to bring tangible value to your manufacturing and production planning processes. By improving user experience and providing deeper analytical insights, we are continuing our commitment to helping you run your operations more intelligently and efficiently. I encourage you to explore these new capabilities and see how they can benefit your team.

 

ATTENTION: SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training 2025 - COMING UP 

A must for all SAP Partners worldwide! 

For the first time, we’re covering the full range of SAP Business Suite, incl. topics such as SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), Spend Management, Supply Chain Management (SCM), Customer Experience (CX), Human Capital Management (HCM), and more, setting a new benchmark in SAP training.

Check it out and see you there!

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud - Resolve High Impact Performance...
entry.content:
You have raised four good points from the SAC Performance Analysis tool. Each one in simple terms:

1. Number of Dimension Attributes: 92

  • Even if attributes are not shown in your widget, they are still part of the underlying query.
  • They need to be read from BW/HANA, so they can slow down performance.
  • If you do not use them at all, it is better to remove unused attributes from the InfoObjects in the query or reduce them via a trimmed view.

2.Number of User-Defined Variable Exits: 8

  • Each variable exit is like a small program that runs to calculate a value dynamically.
  • More exits = more processing time on the backend before the query result is sent to SAC.
  • Eight exits is a bit high, so check if all of them are really needed.

3. Number of Elements in Structure 1: 50

  • “Structure” means a group of measures or key figures defined in your query (for example: sales, cost, profit, ratio, etc.).
  • If you have 50, SAC has to process and transport all 50 each time the widget loads, even if only a few are displayed.
  • Try reducing unnecessary key figures in the query.

4.Number of Free Dimensions: 17

  • “Free dimensions” are dimensions included in the query but not directly in the rows or columns of the table.
  • They still travel with the query so that users can drill down later.
  • Having 17 free dimensions means the query is heavy, and reducing unused free dimensions will improve performance.

In short: Yes, even unused attributes, variable exits, large structures, and free dimensions add weight to your query and can slow SAC widget performance. The best approach is to simplify the underlying BW/HANA query or use a trimmed view with only the fields and dimensions required for the dashboard.

entry.title: CAB Approval Status Not Working in ChaRM Normal Change
entry.content:
Hi Team,


Problem Description:


We enhanced the Normal Change process to introduce a CAB Approval step after QA testing, without using a Request for Change.


A new user status CAB Approvals (E0018) was added between Successfully Tested (40, E0009) and Authorized for Import (50, E0014).
The status profile (ZMJJHEAD) enforces:

40 → 45 → 50
Auth code CABAPP restricts CAB approvals to CAB team only.


We also created a PPF Action (ZMJJ_SET_STATUS_CABAPPROVAL) in Action Profile ZMMJ_ACTIONS to expose this step in WebUI.


Method used: HF_SET_STATUS
Processing Parameter: USER_STATUS = E0018

Observed Issue:

When CAB users try to change the status after Successfully Tested, the system does not offer CAB Approvals in the Actions dropdown. Instead, only “Set Production Status” appears.

Executing this results in error message:

“You can't set status due to status profile customizing or authorizations”
(AI_CRM_CM_MESSAGE070)

Trace (SU53) shows system checking for B_USERSTAT with Auth Code = SMMJ_07 (Authorized for Import), even though CAB should only require CABAPP for status 45.

Steps Taken:

Verified status profile:

45 (CAB Approvals) Lowest=40, Highest=50.
50 (Authorized for Import) Lowest=45, Highest=90.
Ensures CAB step is mandatory.

Verified authorization:

CAB users assigned B_USERSTAT with Auth Code CABAPP for profile ZMJJHEAD.
Basis users retain SMMJ_07.

Verified status codes in table TJ30T:

CAB Approvals = E0018.
Correct value entered in PPF Action parameter.

Implemented Action with HF_SET_STATUS method, parameter USER_STATUS = E0018.

Action is “Executable in Dialog” and “Display in Toolbox”.
Sort Order = 45.

Expected Behavior

After Successfully Tested (40), CAB users should see an action → “Set Status: CAB Approvals”.
Executing it should move the document to CAB Approvals (45, E0018).
Only CAB users (with CABAPP) can approve.
Basis team (with SMMJ_07) can then move 45 → 50 (Authorized for Import).

entry.title: My Learning Journal on BTP (5) - Build A Small Finance Agent: CAP + Generative AI Hub + LangChain
entry.content:
Introduction

This is the fifth blog post in this series.

Good Receipt (GR) Invoice Receipt (IR) mismatches slow down clearing and add noise to month end close. The goal here is a build a small code-based finance agent that explains the mismatch and proposes a next step in one concise result. For example the proposal can be ‘Review invoice quantity against goods receipt and correct any discrepancies’ and ‘Post an adjustment to align GR and IR quantities or contact vendor for clarification on invoiced quantity’.

In my earlier blog on the Procure to Pay process (https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/step-by-step-to-run-a-simple-procure-to-pay-process/ba-p/13448109), the flow from purchase order to goods receipt and invoice receipt was introduced. As an FI consultant, a recurring question I faced is the GR IR mismatch. Why does a line stay open when quantities or values do not align across Purchase Order (PO), GR, and IR. This post continues that thread by introducing a simple finance agent that explains the mismatch and suggests what to do next.

The small finance Agent will be built with SAP CAP Cloud Application Programming Model and Node.js as a small web service that receives each request and communicates with the S/4HANA system. SAP Cloud SDK for AI forwards the request to SAP AI Core Orchestration, where a large language model does the reasoning. LangChain helps turn the request into clear instructions and keeps the answer tidy.

What the Agent delivers:

The response includes the status of the GR/IR check, short reason codes with brief explanations, and the key quantities such as ordered, received, and invoiced amounts. It also proposes a next action, and when appropriate, suggests a simple journal entry as a starting point.

Concepts Introduction                 

  • What is GR IR

GR IR means Goods Receipt and Invoice Receipt. In a P2P (Procure to Pay) flow, a purchase order is created, goods are received, and an invoice is posted.

GR is Good Receipt and IR is Invoice Receipt. A mismatch happens when the purchase order, receipt, and invoice do not align due to partial delivery, delayed posting, or price variance

  • What is Orchestration Workflow

Orchestration Workflows in SAP AI Core is a control layer that standardizes how an application calls large language models and tools. It prepares inputs with reusable templates, applies privacy and safety checks, selects the target model or tool, waits for the reply, and records usage and logs for monitoring and audit. The outcome is consistent, configurable, and reusable execution for every interaction.

Orchestration applies reusable steps such as grounding, templating, masking, and response formatting.

  • What is a ReAct Agent

In this blog post, I will build a ReAct agent. ReAct stands for Reasoning + Acting and follows a simple loop:

  • Thought: reason about the goal and context, decide the next step
  • Action: do one concrete thing, such as call a tool, query a system, or ask a model a focused question
  • Observation: read the result, update a scratchpad, then pick the next Thought

This loop repeats until the agent can return a clear answer.

There are different agent styles, for example ReAct, Plan and Execute, Function or tool-calling, Graph and Workflow agents. I will introduce them in future posts.

  • Agent VS Orchestration
  • What the agent owns
  • Planning the next step with the Thought → Action → Observation loop.
  • Choosing which tool or LLM to use and when to stop.
  • Keeping a scratchpad of evidence and reasoning.
  • What orchestration owns
  • Standardizing inputs and applying policies such as masking or filtering.
  • Routing to the selected model or tool with the right parameters.
  • Reliability, timeouts, retries, and observability.
  • An audit trail of every call.
  • How they work together
  • The agent decides what to do next and produces a clear call and parameters.
  • Orchestration executes that call safely and consistently and returns the result.
  • The agent writes the result into its scratchpad and continues the loop or finishes.
  • What is SAP Cloud SDK for AI

SAP Cloud SDK for AI is a developer kit that connects applications to model services through a single governed entry point. It provides client libraries, message templates, response formatting options, and helpers that integrate with platform services such as credential management and destinations. The value is reduced boilerplate, a unified call path, and consistent alignment with platform governance.

  • What is AI Core in BTP

SAP AI Core is a service on SAP Business Technology Platform for running and governing AI workloads. It offers orchestration for LLM access, policy controls for safety and consistency, deployment management, and usage tracking.

In this blog, AI Core serves as a single-entry point for model calls through Orchestration. Inputs and outputs pass through configurable safeguards and follow a consistent pattern, keeping configuration, policy, and observability in one place with steady behaviour.

  • What is LangChain

LangChain is an open-source toolkit for working with LLM. It provides prompt templates, output parsers, simple chains, and agent helpers. In this series it is used as glue that shapes business inputs into clear instructions for the model and checks that the answer fits the expected structure.

LangChain is used here to keep prompts and outputs consistent across model changes, to enforce a strict JSON schema for the GR/IR summary returned to the CAP service, to route tool calls in a clear ReAct loop without custom plumbing, to add lightweight validation and masking before and after the model call, and to make the agent logic easier to test and maintain with small, composable steps.

Architecture Design

The Agent runs as a small CAP service in the BTP subaccount. SAP Cloud SDK for AI sends requests to SAP AI Core, while LangChain helps format prompts, apply light masking, and validate outputs. When needed, the service reads business context from the S4HANA system through the Destination and the Connectivity service, which can pass the SAP Cloud Connector for on premise access.

Inside the Generative AI Hub, AI Launchpad manages access and AI Core executes an Orchestration flow with optional steps such as grounding, templating, translation, data masking, and filtering. Foundation Model Access then routes the call to a selected foundation model (LLM) and returns the result. Logs and usage are captured along the path so behaviour is observable and repeatable.

The response returns to the CAP service where the agent runs a ReAct loop: the model produces a Thought, the service parses the Action and invokes the corresponding tool such as an S4 query or posting check, records the Observation, and iterates until a Finish action is reached. The final answer is then shaped into an example finance summary.

Pre-request

  • A BTP subaccount with SAP AI Core Extended quota and an SAP AI Launchpad subscription.
  • The BTP subaccount should has the instances created of the necessary services.
  • In SAP AI Launchpad, open Generative AI Hub → Orchestration → Deployments. Select the target resource group with the selector at the top, confirm the deployment Status is RUNNING, then open the entry to view details and copy the API URL.
  • A service key for the SAP AI Core instance provided as the environment variable AICORE_SERVICE_KEY.
  • The Orchestration deployment API URL is stored in the environment variable ORCH_DEPLOYMENT_URL.
  • Development can run locally with Node.js 18 or later and the CAP command line interface, in SAP Business Application Studio or Visual Studio Code.
  • A S/4HANA system with the APIs activated and can be connected by SAP Cloud Connector.

Business/Function Background

Within SAP Financial Accounting (FI), GR/IR (Goods Receipt / Invoice Receipt) reconciliation ensures that the Good Receipt posted against a Purchase Order matches the corresponding Invoice Receipt. When a mismatch occurs, the review focuses on quantities, prices, or missing postings.

In this blog, there is a Purchase Order in the S/4HANA system shows an amount mismatch between GR and IR. The code-based Finance Agent analyses this PO by reading Good Receipt 101 movements and related supplier invoice (Invoice Receipt) references from S/4HANA through the corresponding APIs, then returns key information such as status, reason codes, ordered, received, and invoiced, and based on this information generates a suggestion and a proposal.

Configurations in SAP AI Launchpad and SAP AI Core

a. Generative AI Hub

Generative AI Hub is the area in SAP AI Launchpad where Foundation Models and Orchestration flows are managed. It provides a single entry point to select an LLM, deploy it into a Resource Group, and expose a stable endpoint for consumption. It also offers Usage Metering, Logs, and Access Control so activity is controlled.

In this blog, the first step is to configure the Orchestration flow in Generative AI Hub. The flow can include steps such as grounding, templating, translation, data masking, and filtering. Data masking is a key step, since it hides or replaces sensitive details such as credit card numbers, email addresses, or person names while keeping the business context usable. After data masking is configured, key information is masked before the request is sent to the LLM.

Another key configuration in orchestration is the model configuration. This step selects the LLM for the flow and sets parameters such as max tokens and temperature. Selecting a prefer LLM and keeping temperature low helps the flow return strict JSON consistently. The model configuration is saved with the orchestration workflow and becomes part of the deployed artifact in the selected resource group. After the workflow is built and deployed, the deployment exposes the live endpoint that the CAP Finance Agent service consumes.
‘Temperature’ controls randomness in word choice. Lower values produce more stable and repeatable answers, while higher values introduce more variation and creativity in the output.

The LLM can be used in the Orchestration configuration can be found under the Model Library.

b. Build and Deploy the Orchestration Flow

After the orchestration flow is configured, build and deploy it. The deployment appears in ML Operations → Deployments, grouped by Resource Group. When the status is RUNNING, open the entry and find the API URL. This URL is the live Orchestration endpoint consumed by outside.

Codes Snipes

In this blog, the Finance Agent uses real S/4HANA figures to form the recommendation and proposal. The key difference between an Agent and a simple Orchestration call is that the Agent iterates through a loop until the objective is fulfilled. It can fetch facts, re-evaluate, and only then finalize the result. In this scenario, LangChain structures the prompts, applies light masking, and drives a short loop that can add S/4HANA facts when confidence is low. A quality gate then requires a clear status, valid ordered/received/invoiced quantities, no uncertain reason codes, and a concrete suggestion with a practical proposal.

The agent runs up to three checks. For this agent, three rounds are sufficient to improve quality without unnecessary time or cost. If an early pass is not confident, the agent enriches the run with system of record data from S/4HANA so the explanation and recommendation reflect actual Good Receipt 101 totals and supplier invoice references. This is why an agent pattern is preferred over a single one shot call to the LLM.

Below are sample code snippets.

File structure

FinanceAgent/

└─ srv/

   ├─ service.cds

   ├─ agent-service.js

   └─ catalog-service.js

service.cds

Defines the Finance Agent action and the fixed seven field result, plus a small catalog view for PO headers.

using { cuid } from '@sap/cds/common';
@path: 'finance-agent'
@impl: './agent-service.js'
service FinanceAgentService {
  type CheckInput {
    companyCode        : String;
    purchasingDocument : String;
    item               : String;
    currency           : String;
    language           : String;
    email              : String;
    phone              : String;
    person             : String;
  }
  type CheckResult {
    status      : String;
    reasonCodes : array of String;
    ordered     : Decimal(13,3);
    received    : Decimal(13,3);
    invoiced    : Decimal(13,3);
    suggestion  : String;
    proposal    : String;
  }
  action check(input: CheckInput) returns CheckResult;
}

@path: 'catalog'
@impl: './catalog-service.js'
service CatalogService {
  .persistence.skip
  entity POs {
    key PurchaseOrder     : String(20);
        CompanyCode       : String(4);
        Supplier          : String(10);
        DocumentCurrency  : String(5);
        PurchaseOrderType : String(4);
        PurchaseOrderDate : Date;
  }
}

agent-service.js

Implements prompts, schema enforcement, light masking, a short quality gate, and a three round loop that can add S/4HANA facts.

  • Strict JSON schema and Orchestration clien
import { OrchestrationClient } from '@sap-ai-sdk/langchain'
import { JsonOutputParser } from '@langchain/core/output_parsers'

const RESPONSE_SCHEMA = {
  type: 'json_schema',
  json_schema: {
    name: 'finance_check',
    strict: true,
    schema: {
      type: 'object',
      properties: {
        status: { type: 'string' },
        reasonCodes: { type: 'array', items: { type: 'string' } },
        ordered: { type: 'number' },
        received: { type: 'number' },
        invoiced: { type: 'number' },
        suggestion: { type: 'string' },
        proposal: { type: 'string' }
      },
      required: ['status','reasonCodes','ordered','received','invoiced','suggestion','proposal'],
      additionalProperties: false
    }
  }
}

const client = new OrchestrationClient({
  llm: { model_name: process.env.MODEL_NAME || 'gpt-4o' },
  templating: { response_format: RESPONSE_SCHEMA }
})
const jsonParser = new JsonOutputParser()

Short prompt templates

The system template sets the overall instruction for the agent, telling it to act as a GR and IR reconciliation assistant and to return only valid JSON that matches the schema.
The user template shapes the specific business input, such as company code, purchase order, item, currency, and language.

import { ChatPromptTemplate } from '@langchain/core/prompts'

const SYS_TEMPLATE =
  'You are a GR/IR reconciliation assistant. ' +
  'Given the business inputs, analyze GR/IR and return ONLY valid JSON that matches the schema. No prose.'

const USER_TEMPLATE =
  'companyCode: {companyCode}, purchasingDocument: {purchasingDocument}, ' +
  'item: {item}, currency: {currency}, language: {language}'

const userPrompt = ChatPromptTemplate.fromTemplate(USER_TEMPLATE)

CAP wiring for 'Check' action

This handler connects the FinanceAgentService.check action to the implementation. Each request is passed to runAgent, which returns the strict JSON result or a controlled error payload.

import cds from '@sap/cds'

// runAgent is defined above in this file
export default cds.service.impl(function () {
  this.on('check', async req => {
    try {
      const res = await runAgent(req.data?.input || {})
      return res
    } catch (e) {
      const cause = e?.cause?.response?.data || e?.response?.data || e?.message || String(e)
      req.error(500, 'Orchestration call failed', { cause })
    }
  })
})

catalog-service.js

Communicates with S/4HANA using three OData APIs for PO header, GR 101 totals, and supplier invoice references.

// shared S4 fetch helper
export async function s4Fetch(path, params) { /* build URL with $format=json and sap-client, call fetch, return JSON */ }

// header
export async function fetchPOHeader(po) { /* call API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV A_PurchaseOrder('<po>') with $select fields */ }

// aggregates
export async function fetchAggFromGRIR(po, item) {
  // received from API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV A_MaterialDocumentItem filter GoodsMovementType eq '101'
  // invoiced from API_SUPPLIERINVOICE_PROCESS_SRV A_SuplrInvcItemPurOrdRef
  return { ordered: 0, received, invoiced }

Result

The service returns a short, consistent result with seven pieces of information: status, reasons, ordered quantity, received quantity, invoiced quantity, a suggestion, and a proposal. It is easy to read and can be used by another system without extra work.

Before returning the suggestion and proposal, the service performs several checks. It verifies that the result follows the expected format, confirms that the quantities are valid numbers, and rejects any uncertain reason codes. If the outcome is not clear, it looks up real figures from S/4HANA such as Good Receipt 101 totals and related supplier invoice (Invoice Receipt) references, and then tries again. If the result is still not reliable, a controlled fallback message is provided instead of guessing.

The suggestion and proposal are generated based on these verified S/4HANA numbers. For example, if an invoice quantity is higher than the goods received, the output may include the suggestion “Review invoice quantity against goods receipt and correct any discrepancies.” and the proposal “Post an adjustment to align GR and IR quantities or contact vendor for clarification on invoiced quantity.”

Conclusion and Next Blog

The code-based Finance Agent delivers a small, consistent result for GR and IR reconciliation using the S4HANA figures, a quality gate, and a suggestion with a proposal.

The next blog will deepen the design by introducing MCP to standardize how context and tools are supplied to the model, using LangGraph to organize the iterative flow into compact nodes for prompting, grounding, validation, and decision, adding A2A handoff so one agent can request checks or approvals from another agent.

If you are also interested in AI, you can find me on LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/zhengzhang-jason-lu-42574b41/

Keep learning, keep growing.

entry.title: deprecated Job Section field in Employee Central
entry.content:
We have an issue with the implementation of our Employee Central integration and need confirmation from SAP over a technical question. It relates to a field (called Job Section) which SAP have communicated is deprecated, but they haven’t removed it. 

Our SuccessFactors build requires the Job Section field to be enabled (the system is configured to check two fields for the Paygroup ID, the Job Section being one of these fields)  

Our customer does not currently use this section, but they have proposed a workaround to help unblock the issue. 

What we require is confirmation from SAP that they will not remove the deprecated Job Section field in the future – otherwise the proposed workaround will not work.

entry.title: Re: CrystalDecisions.Shared.CrystalReportsException is no...
entry.content:
First issue is you are using 13.0.2000.0, that suggests your are using a VERY OLD version of CR's .NET assemblies. 2000 is the old 2.0/1.2 Framework required, newer versions will show them as 13.0.4000.0.

You need to upgrade to the latest SP 38 from here:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/crystalreports/3354091173.html?locale=en-US

See this blog I wrote to upgrade to current versions:

Upgrading a Visual Studio 2008->2022 .NET project with the latest CR .NET SDK packages

Quick upgrade note, project must be set to 4.7 or 4.8 Framework, only supported versions now.

Second is not the location of the Assemblies have changed.

Third is when you upgrade to SP 38 uninstall the previous version first and right click on the EXE, note there are separate installers for VS 2010->2019 and a 64 bit installer for VS 2022, install the 32 bit runtime also at the end of the installer, it's required only for the VS install.

See if that resolves your issues.
